update.description:
Some additions to @mohamd_ayman's work on pull request #140:

* Serve `index.html` directly from `localhost:port`
* Commented code
* Use `const` and `let` on server code
* Check `server.js` with eslint
* Reword many of the console messages
* Serve websocket from the same http server which serves the static content - I'm not entirely sure this is ok, was there a reason for the separate port? @iche033
update.title: Additions to pull request #140

content.raw: Ticketed issue #143 for the example, that example would also verify whether the textures are working and the issue can be tackled from there
content.html: Ticketed issue #143 for the example, that example would also verify whether the textures are working and the issue can be tackled from there

content.raw: +1, thanks. If the minimum version we're targeting is node 4, what do you think of changing pipelines? (doesn't need to be on this PR)
content.html: +1, thanks. If the minimum version we're targeting is node 4, what do you think of changing pipelines? (doesn't need to be on this PR)

content.raw:
Made some changes:
	
896a4f7 - added `use strict` so it works with node version v4

b1434c2 - declare `wsServer` 

5c68dd6 - create `http/client/assets` empty dir if not present otherwise it was crashing on browser connect
content.html:
Made some changes:

896a4f7 - added use strict so it works with node version v4

b1434c2 - declare wsServer

5c68dd6 - create http/client/assets empty dir if not present otherwise it was crashing on browser connect

content.raw: Oh I see, I didn't know there was node on Ubuntu, I always custom install it. I'm ok with reverting this to var then.
content.html: Oh I see, I didn't know there was node on Ubuntu, I always custom install it. I'm ok with reverting this to var then.

content.raw: works after updating node version to v6.12.1. Note that by default xenial comes with v4.2.6. So we may need to provide instructions to let users know to use a newer version of nodejs.
content.html: works after updating node version to v6.12.1. Note that by default xenial comes with v4.2.6. So we may need to provide instructions to let users know to use a newer version of nodejs.

content.raw: I'm getting an error regarding the use of `let`. Did you have to use strict mode? I'm on node version v4.2.6
content.html: I'm getting an error regarding the use of let. Did you have to use strict mode? I'm on node version v4.2.6

content.raw: No particular reason for separate ports. We can try using the same port number.
content.html: No particular reason for separate ports. We can try using the same port number.

content.raw: @iche033 , this is part of the `gzweb_embedded` branch
content.html: @iche033 , this is part of the gzweb_embedded branch

content.raw: I see, Great idea!
content.html: I see, Great idea!

content.raw: I checked that the changes here don't break the current behavior. I'm making an embedded example similar to the one on pull request #141, but which uses the backend. It is working for meshes but not for textures yet, I'm trying to be consistent with pull request #141 though.
content.html: I checked that the changes here don't break the current behavior. I'm making an embedded example similar to the one on pull request #141, but which uses the backend. It is working for meshes but not for textures yet, I'm trying to be consistent with pull request #141 though.

content.raw: Did we make sure that the meshes are loaded from a `URL` on this branch, or you mean the other separate branch?
content.html: Did we make sure that the meshes are loaded from a URL on this branch, or you mean the other separate branch?

content.raw:
Pushed a few more changes:

* optional `url` argument for `gziface`, defaults to current location
* made sure meshes are being loaded from that URL
* **TODO** make sure textures are loaded from that URL
* Substituted emitter `error` for `connectionError` because `error` has a [special meaning](https://nodejs.org/api/events.html#events_error_events) and closes the application if there are no listeners.
* **TODO** add example / test where resources are pulled from a different URL
content.html:
Pushed a few more changes:

  • optional url argument for gziface, defaults to current location
  • made sure meshes are being loaded from that URL
  • TODO make sure textures are loaded from that URL
  • Substituted emitter error for connectionError because error has a special meaning and closes the application if there are no listeners.
  • TODO add example / test where resources are pulled from a different URL

content.raw: Pushed just that here, still needs testing though
content.html: Pushed just that here, still needs testing though

content.raw: +1, I'm doing this on a separate branch
content.html: +1, I'm doing this on a separate branch

content.raw: yeah makes sense, we can also make it optional, like in if users don't want to connect to `gzserver` they wouldn't have to see error messages.
content.html: yeah makes sense, we can also make it optional, like in if users don't want to connect to gzserver they wouldn't have to see error messages.

content.raw: Actually now I think a more general approach would be to offer the user a way to set the url instead of getting it from the window. That would be useful when embedding GzWeb into another site and it is pulling data from a different URL.
content.html: Actually now I think a more general approach would be to offer the user a way to set the url instead of getting it from the window. That would be useful when embedding GzWeb into another site and it is pulling data from a different URL.

content.raw:
O I see!, Sorry I must have mixed between things.

Yeah we cant change the value of the `const`, not just the data type as I thought.
content.html:
O I see!, Sorry I must have mixed between things.

Yeah we cant change the value of the const, not just the data type as I thought.

content.raw:
I think we wouldn't be able to assign it a new boolean value, such as on line 127, if it were `const`. Try this for example:

~~~
$ node
> const isConnected = false;
undefined
> isConnected = true;
TypeError: Assignment to constant variable.
    at repl:1:13
    at sigintHandlersWrap (vm.js:22:35)
    at sigintHandlersWrap (vm.js:96:12)
    at ContextifyScript.Script.runInThisContext (vm.js:21:12)
    at REPLServer.defaultEval (repl.js:313:29)
    at bound (domain.js:280:14)
    at REPLServer.runBound [as eval] (domain.js:293:12)
    at REPLServer.<anonymous> (repl.js:513:10)
    at emitOne (events.js:101:20)
    at REPLServer.emit (events.js:188:7)
~~~
content.html:
I think we wouldn't be able to assign it a new boolean value, such as on line 127, if it were const. Try this for example:

$ node
> const isConnected = false;
undefined
> isConnected = true;
TypeError: Assignment to constant variable.
    at repl:1:13
    at sigintHandlersWrap (vm.js:22:35)
    at sigintHandlersWrap (vm.js:96:12)
    at ContextifyScript.Script.runInThisContext (vm.js:21:12)
    at REPLServer.defaultEval (repl.js:313:29)
    at bound (domain.js:280:14)
    at REPLServer.runBound [as eval] (domain.js:293:12)
    at REPLServer.<anonymous> (repl.js:513:10)
    at emitOne (events.js:101:20)
    at REPLServer.emit (events.js:188:7)

content.raw: Ah you mean there are some parts of the code that might change the `isConnected` from a `boolean` to something else.
content.html: Ah you mean there are some parts of the code that might change the isConnected from a boolean to something else.

content.raw: The thing is that this variable may be changed along the code, so it isn't really constant
content.html: The thing is that this variable may be changed along the code, so it isn't really constant

content.raw:
Why did you decide to go for a `let` here?

I mean wouldn't it be better to use `const` if we knew the data type.
content.html:
Why did you decide to go for a let here?

I mean wouldn't it be better to use const if we knew the data type.
